text:
nano docs/WaterInsecurity.html nano docs/search.json nano docs/CDCdatasets.html nano replacements.txt nano docs/WaterInsecurity.html nano docs/search.json nano docs/CDCdatasets.html nano replacements.txt 31b8e172-b470-440e-83d8-e6b185028602::31b8e172-b470-440e-83d8-e6b185028602
Data curated by Niha Pereira for Tidy Tuesday from U.S. Census Bureau data.

library(tidytuesdayR)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(ggplot2)
Sys.setenv(GITHUB_PAT="")
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2025-01-28')

---- Compiling #TidyTuesday Information for 2025-01-28 ----


--- There are 2 files available ---


── Downloading files ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

  1 of 2: "water_insecurity_2022.csv"
  2 of 2: "water_insecurity_2023.csv"

water_insecurity_2022 <- tuesdata$water_insecurity_2022
water_insecurity_2023 <- tuesdata$water_insecurity_2023
water_insecurity_2022 <- water_insecurity_2022 |>  
 dplyr::mutate(
    geometry = purrr::map(geometry, \(geo) {
      eval(parse(text = geo))
    } )
  )
water_insecurity_2023 <- water_insecurity_2023 |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    geometry = purrr::map(geometry, \(geo) {
      eval(parse(text = geo))
    } )
  )

top10_lacking <- water_insecurity_2022 |>
  mutate(greatest_lacking=percent_lacking_plumbing) |>
  arrange(desc(greatest_lacking)) |>
  slice_head(n=10)
  
ggplot(top10_lacking, aes(x=reorder(name, greatest_lacking), y=greatest_lacking))+
  geom_col(fill="pink")+
  coord_flip()+
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 areas lacking plumbing in the U.S. in 2022",
    x="County Name", 
    y="Percent Lacking Plumbing"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
